subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Is this group defunct?
msgSnippet: It can be difficult to have corrections made to Memrise courses, since most of them are user-contributed, and can only be changed by the one who made them.
messageBody:
It can be difficult to have corrections made to Memrise courses, since most of them are user-contributed, and can only be changed by the one who made them. What I’d like to see is somebody who knows what they’re doing to make some good-quality QS Memrise courses (since this is a popular tool) and then at least have some correct information out there. Maybe I’ll work on that in my non-existent free time. :)

And in the meantime, I agree, the Memrise course that’s out there is probably not a good resource to rely on. Better to start from the Manual and work from there.

Benjamin Bruce


On Tue, Jul 11, 2017 at 10:05 AM, 'C. Paige Gabhart' cpgabhart@... [Read_Alphabet] <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
 

Tvindy,

Initial note: I have placed the names of letters in parentheses.)

I have taken a quick look at memrise and mistakes popped out at me very quickly.  Here are some examples of this:

In lesson 2 (no. 27) the vowel (Eat) is improperly shapedj .  The second stroke should be vertical, not slanted.  I am not sure what font the author used for these lessons although I remember seeing it before.  In some words in memrise, the letter "eat" is formed correctly, in other places,  the author used this improperly shaped form.  Obviously, you don't want the shape of "eat" to flip back and forth since you are trying to build a connection in your mind between the letter shape and the sound.

Lesson 4 - the word "anger" is misspelled.  The initial vowel should be "at" followed by "ing, not "no".  The next word "hunger" is also misspelled.  "No" is used instead of "ing" once again.  The next word "singing" is also mispelled.  We have "ing" at the end of the word, but it is missing in the middle where again he uses "no".  The next word is "anchor."  Again we need "ing" and the author uses "no."  It seems evident he does not understand when "ing" is required.

I don't have time to continue looking for mistakes but based on what I have seen so far, I would be very cautious about using memrise as a source for accurate information on learning QS.  For a beginner, it would be hard to recognize what is correct and what is not.

I would suggest that you download the QS manual from the Read Alphabet site (qs manual modern (beta), which was written by Kingsley Read, so you can see the proper form of all the letters and study the writing examples which it contains.  Once you have done that, the mistakes in memrise should be more obvious to you.

Good luck.

Paige


On 7/10/2017 8:27 PM, tvindy@... [Read_Alphabet] wrote:
 

I'm glad to know people are still interested. I'm currently working on being able to read quickscript junior, which I can already do extremely slowly.


Here's the link to the Memrise course: https://www.memrise. com/course/784058/quickscript- for-beginners/
